data.text:
Cross-posting is a great way to grow your impressions üìà 

‚ùó But, there is one crucial thing you need to do to make sure you're not penalised.

In this post, I share my recommendations for cross-posting and how to do it right.

#100DaysOfCode

üîó https://t.co/Eq8yanxmfJ

@SimonHoiberg Great advice Simon, completely agree! üî•

I think the key is what you are comparing. 

Where you & the other person currently are, is likely different. Where you're going is likely different. 

But, that doesn't mean you don't share the same path. 

Learn from them. üí™

How I cope with the mornings üòç 

Think I might have a slight addiction ü§î https://t.co/Y8jQngQEhg

Helpful Advice üëç

Yesterday, I heard someone say a piece of advice and it really stuck with me so I wanted to share it with you all:

üí¨ Don't take criticism from someone, who you wouldn't take advice from.  

Simple and effective!

We all have a finite amount of energy to use, make sure you're using it right. üòÉ

‚ùå Don't channel your energy into negative activities like bringing people down.

‚úÖ Channel your energy into creating positive changes in the world and helping people improve.

üî• JavaScript Tip üî•

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Counting occurrences of values in an array and return counts in an array of objects.

‚úèÔ∏è I've used this when making the tags on my blog.

‚ùì Have you used this before?
‚ùì Will you use this going forward?

--
#100DaysOfCode #JavaScript https://t.co/ZrkFhQ3FVy

Want to know more about Higher Order Functions In JavaScript? 

üëâ What are they?
üëâ How to use them?
üëâ Examples?

Check out the link below for my public notes on them üòÑ 

#100DaysOfCode #developers

üîó https://t.co/yJr6XoG9w8

‚ùì Got some questions or  info

If you have any questions, recommendations that I've missed or just want to chat be sure to drop it below! üòÄ ‚è¨ 7/7

5Ô∏è‚É£ Pick up a book

One of the best ways to improve your writing is reading!

By reading books and others work you're exposing yourself to more of the language and how to write it effectively. ‚è¨ 6/7

Want some recommendations? Check out my list below:

üîó https://t.co/ZXljgjxdnG

4Ô∏è‚É£ The Most Dangerous Writing App

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Find yourself trying to edit your content as you create? 
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Keep stopping mid-writing? 

These are both problems this site aims to fix. While extreme, if you stop writing it deletes the entire draft! ü§Ø ‚è¨ 5/7

üîó https://t.co/7O1gyNdQlX

3Ô∏è‚É£ Forest App

While not a tool that directly helps you improve your writing.

The Forest App will help you get your content onto the page!

Forest allows you to implement the Pomodoro productivity method to ensure you focus on your content. ‚è¨ 4/7

üîó https://t.co/WrUdQGJL7A

2Ô∏è‚É£ Hemingway Editor

Ever find yourself writing overly complicated sentences and never able to trim them down? Or, want to make your content easier to read by removing hard to read sentences? 

Then the Hemingway Editor if for you! ‚è¨ 3/7

üîó https://t.co/sDk7YIGH91

1Ô∏è‚É£ Grammarly

Grammarly is an online tool that has a free & paid version. While the paid version does more, if you're just using it to check your spelling & grammar is on point the free one will be just fine. ‚è¨ 2/7

‚ûï They have a browser extension

üîó https://t.co/lczxvxM7hH

‚úèÔ∏è Blogging / Writing Aids ‚úèÔ∏è

Writing high quality, accurate content is already hard enough so having to be an English language expert just makes this challenge even harder.

But, luckily there are some tools and tips that make this easier. ‚è¨ üßµ 1/7
--
#100DaysOfCode #Blogging https://t.co/Dj48rRVZtL

@ninan_phillip @FeedHive_io @NotionHQ Completely agree üëç Notion is an absolute game changer for pretty much everything in my life. 

I definitely need to get on the Kanban boards for my projects and I love the new timeline feature they brought in.

@ninan_phillip I tend to lean more towards Grammarly all the time and only run blog posts through Hemingway. 

So blog posts get both while pretty much everything else is grammarly. But that's mainly because grammarly has a browser extension.

‚ùì Got some questions or  info

If you have any questions, recommendations that I've missed or just want to chat be sure to drop them below! üòÄ ‚è¨ 7/7

5Ô∏è‚É£ Pick up a book

One of the best ways to improve your writing is reading!

By reading books and others work you're exposing yourself to more of the language and how to write it effectively. ‚è¨ 6/7

Want some recommendations? Check out my list below:

üîó https://t.co/ZXljgjfBZ6

4Ô∏è‚É£ The Most Dangerous Writing App

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Find yourself trying to edit your content as you create? 
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Keep stopping mid-writing? 

These are both problems this site aims to fix. While extreme, if you stop writing it deletes the entire draft! ü§Ø‚è¨ 5/7

üîó https://t.co/7O1gyNdQlX

urls.title: Optimising Google Fonts for Increased Performance on GatsbyJS.
urls.description: GatsbyJS makes blazing fasts websites already but often importing fonts can be the achilles heel, here's how to optimise Google Fonts for increased performance.

data.text:

urls.title: This is an obsolete API and is no longer guaranteed to work.
urls.description: The __proto__ property of Object.prototype is an accessor property (a getter function and a setter function) that exposes the internal [[Prototype]] (either an object or null) of the object through which it is accessed.

data.text:
‚ùó The use of __proto__ ‚ùó

I have used __proto__ a few times throughout this thread but this shouldn't be done unless for demonstration as this syntax is now deprecated.

Instead use, Object.getPrototypeOf & Object.setPrototypeOf

üîó https://t.co/92hXo0Q5mQ

15/15

6Ô∏è‚É£ Looping - Checking Object.prototype

You may notice that when we loop through the inherited properties, methods like '.keys()' are not shown, why?

Because the Object.prototype has the 'enumerable:false' flag & a for..in loop skips anything with this flag. 14/15

6Ô∏è‚É£ Looping - Checking if a property exists on the object

If you want to see if a property exists within the object or has been inherited you can by using: 

'Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty()'

This will return a boolean value for every property, see the üñºÔ∏è for more... 13/15 https://t.co/JauFrboMds

6Ô∏è‚É£ Looping

If we want to see the properties on an object we can use 'Object.keys()' but this excludes inherited properties so we can't see the properties from the prototype.

If we want to do this, we can use a 'for..in' loop like shown in the image. 12/15 https://t.co/lNho1or6HN

5Ô∏è‚É£ ".this" example

In our getters/setters from earlier, we used 'foodShop.age = 10', this called the setter which used ".this". 

The " this" referred to 'foodShop' and not 'shop' even though the setter was stored within 'shop'.

Another example in the üñºÔ∏è  11/15 https://t.co/5uIdwsHSUj

5Ô∏è‚É£ ".this"

The simple rule when it comes to using the "this" keyword with the prototype is:

**No matter where the method is found whether the object itself or the prototype chain. When calling a method the "this" keyword always refers to the object before the dot.** 

10/15

4Ô∏è‚É£ Accessor Properties Exceptions

The only exception to the read-only rule is getters and setters.

When using getters and setters we use the methods defined in the chain but the individual values are stored within the objects themselves. (More on this in a bit) 9/15 https://t.co/GeKhOwXg7E

4Ô∏è‚É£ Read Only

The prototype is only used for reading properties, when it comes to writing/deleting properties they are added or removed to the object it was called on regardless if it's in the prototype or not. 8/15 https://t.co/lqLUnBbv4e

üîó Chain Examples

In the image, there are 3 examples showing the different situations of our example above.

1 - No Prototype
2 - One Custom Prototype 
3 - Two Custom Prototype

By default, all objects will finish with the last prototype being Object.prototype. 7/15 https://t.co/APzyrtXiSZ

3Ô∏è‚É£ The Chain

Prototypal Inheritance is actually quite logical, it looks within itself and then works up the chain every time it can't find the requested property.

This process continues until it finds the property or it reaches the end of the chain which is null. 6/15

...it looks within itself first, if it can find the property there it executes it. 

However, if the property isn't found within itself it then looks up the chain to the next link which we had set to the 'shop object.

As the property existed there it logged it out. 5/15

The reason we can log out the property from the first object by accessing it on the second object after setting the prototype is because of prototypal inheritance.

Once the prototype is set, the chain is formed. When we try to access a property on an object... ‚è¨ 4/15

2Ô∏è‚É£ Example

In the image, we have 2 objects with different properties in them. 

We try to log out the property from the first object by accessing it on the second object and unsurprisingly it doesn't work. ‚ùå 

But, once we set the prototype it works. ‚úÖ

Why is this? 3/15 https://t.co/uNILsOCf8T

1Ô∏è‚É£ What is it?

"Prototypal inheritance is the process an object uses in JavaScript to lookup properties and methods from its prototype should it not be found in the current object. "

Essentially, it allows us to use the methods and properties from another object. 2/15

üü° JS: Prototypal Inheritence Explained üü°

Prototypal Inheritance is one of those terms that sounds intimidating and complicated but it's not! In this thread, I'm going to cover what it is and how we use it. üßµ 1/15
--

üëâ I'm waking up earlier to give myself time to work on my goals prior to starting work for the day.
üëâ I'm going to develop by carving out a section of time every day to practice coding.
üëâ I keep my self accountable by keeping a tick sheet that I need to do every day.

Success isn't created by one large change in behaviour, it's created by the compound impact of many small ones.

üëâ What are you trying differently this week? 
üëâ How are you going to develop this week?
üëâ What steps are you taking towards your goal?

I'll go first üëá

@catalinmpit I always get stuck on this. I love the idea of having a blog with my name. But what happens if in the future I want to blog about something unrelated to tech it's not what people would expect. 

What about starting a new blog and post on both but canonical link to the new one?

@FrancescoCiull4 Completely agree! üëç Recently started doing the same and besides the productivity benefits I actually feel a lot healthier and happier because of it. 

Not sure if that's down to the extra productivity or actually getting 8 hours sleep though. ü§î Either way I love it üòÉ

What's everyone using for note taking apps and places to store client contact and project info? 

Is Notion still the big thing? Or, are there better solutions available now? 

Security and privacy is the priority, not necessarily for my notes but 100% for client info.

I've never known how to price freelance projects and this thread offers great insight into how to do just that. 

If you find yourself in a similar situation check out the awesome thread by Dan below üëá https://t.co/zH3qmAEI6R

@SimonHoiberg Enough to not have to worry about the venture going south. 

If required enough to see me through till I got a more stable income.
@SimonHoiberg @FeedHive_io Can't wait üòÉ

@SimonHoiberg @FeedHive_io This is an awesome client, I use it myself on my website to draw my latest tweets in via a serverless function. Couldn't be easier üëç

Quick question is it built on Twitter V1 or V2 API?

@SimonHoiberg @KennethCassel 100% üëç 

Whenever a client asks me to setup an email client for them I go to GSuite 100% of time. No messing around with email servers and you get Google's reliability and a UI pretty much everyone is use to.

@SimonHoiberg Would you suggest LinkedIn as a good place for individuals with little experience to find clients? 

LinkedIn seems to be a great platform for finding clients but I only really see more established and experienced developers talk about it.

@SimonHoiberg No problem üëç

Happy to be a part of this amazing journey, keep up the great work üî•

@SimonHoiberg This is awesome news Simon üî•

Feedhive has great potential I can't wait to see where it ends up. üòÉ
@qlikArpe Seems like a good book, thanks for the recommendation üòÉ

üìö What is everything reading now days? 

I've got some time off work so I'm planning on finally finishing this book. Any recommendations on what to start next? ü§î https://t.co/PNQvgbW9k1
@dan_spratling @FeedHive_io This looks incredible üî•

üë§ My Favourite

Personally, I always go for the .map() or .forEach() method depending on the situation, in general, I've moved away from traditional loops when it comes to looping through an array.

How about you? üí¨ 6/7

4Ô∏è‚É£ .map()

.map() is actually very similar to .forEach() with one key difference. 

When using .forEach() we can only iterate through the array and not return anything. But, when we use .map() we can return values from the callback function as shown in the üñºÔ∏è. 5/7 https://t.co/VXcjJUeezg

3Ô∏è‚É£ .forEach()

More recently introduced to the language, the .forEach() method is built into the Array.prototype and allows for us to directly loop over an array without calling a loop explicitly.

In fact, it actually uses loops underneath but just makes the syntax simpler. 4/7 https://t.co/bm1OUtc4oY

2Ô∏è‚É£ While Loop

A slightly more unusual way of looping through arrays is the while loop. 

Similar to the for loop, the while loop will loop while a condition is true but unlike a for loop, it doesn't have a pre-determined end and instead will go forever while true. 3/7 https://t.co/XqpGkWw6x2

1Ô∏è‚É£ For Loop

The for loop is one of the fundamentals of the language due to its versatility. It's no different when it comes to looping over an array.

The for loop works by creating a variable and incrementing it while a condition is true, we then access the index. 2/7 https://t.co/tOJTWQSkYE

üü° JS: Looping over Arrays üü° 

Looping over arrays is such a massive part of handling data in JavaScript that I wanted to cover some of the most common methods of doing so in this thread. 

Let me know your favourite üí¨ 1/7
--
#100DaysOfCode #JavaScript #developers https://t.co/EbqSKO29p7
@SimonHoiberg Awesome work Simon üî•
@SimonHoiberg @FeedHive_io This is awesome üî• Happy to be a part of that 3000 as well üòÑ
@florinpop1705 I know right, might take some time to master that one. üòÇ
@florinpop1705 HTML....üëÄ

As someone looking to make a SaaS product in the near future, this video from @SimonHoiberg was super helpful. üî•

If you're interested in making a SaaS product highly recommend you check it out ‚è¨

https://t.co/o7w1BQDf3K

üëá Check this offer out üëá

I've been using Feedhive since the start of Feb and it's been the best purchase I've made all year! 

Seriously upped my Twitter game üí™ https://t.co/Jq3wsGvYba

This is thread 28/28 in my February Twitter Thread Challenge. üìÜ

If you're interested in following along in my challenge or like this thread's content and want to see more please consider retweeting it for others to see and following me for future threads. üòÄ 17/17

‚ùì Questions ‚ùì 

Now we're done, we have a fully functioning form that traps spam submissions from bots using a honeypot.

If you have any questions please drop them down below and I'll get back to you as soon as I can.

16/17

üîó Example

If you're interested in seeing this in action or fancy giving it a shot üòú check out the links below:

üîó https://t.co/hVtzhYQeHP

If you want to see the code, check out:

üîó https://t.co/DYpz3Sl38m

15/17

üçØ Hiding the form field

Believe it or not, we can just use a simple display: none on the honeypot field to hide it from view for human users.

This works as the DOM element is still there for computers to detect in the form but it won't show it for users. Awesome üòÑ 

14/17 https://t.co/FW0JkLi0Pg

üçØ Discarding submissions with this form

This field isn't required to be filled in as it'll only be filled in by bots. We pass this field to the serverless function and check for its existence.

If it does exist we return a status code 400 and a custom error. 13/17 https://t.co/MeQ3Xej1Ot

üçØ What is a honeypot?

"It's a sacrificial computer system that's intended to attract cyberattacks, like a decoy."

We are creating a field in the form that human users won't be able to see but computers will. 

So, any bots populating the form will be trapped. 

12/17

üåü Complete? üåü 

This is now the base setup complete, we can sign emails up to our newsletter & display the outcome to the user.

However, you may have noticed a few mentions to 'chilliIsCool' in my code, what's this?

This is a  honeypot, let's take a look.

11/17

7Ô∏è‚É£ Displaying the message

Once we have set the message and error state this is returned to the original emailSignupForm Component to be displayed to the user.

10/17 https://t.co/Sq3GXf7TcU

6Ô∏è‚É£ Setting the outcome message/state

In the 'useEmail' file, we set multiple states depending on the HTML code. These are:

üëâüèª setLoading: used for waiting for the serverless function
üëâüèª setError: true if an error
üëâüèª setMessage: Message to display to the user

9/17 https://t.co/xyeJBm3IK1

5Ô∏è‚É£ HTML Codes

Inside the 'useEmail' file, once we have a reply returned to us from the serverless function, we check to see what HTML code we get back:

‚úÖ 200
‚ùå >= 400 && < 600

If you want to read more check out:

üîó https://t.co/KnpI2TLq3Y

8/17

4Ô∏è‚É£ Serverless Function

If the 'useEmail' file receives an email then it will be posted to the serverless function which handles:

üëâüèª Check for required fields (email) 
üëâüèª Posting to ConverKit for the signup
üëâüèª Returning a success message back to 'useEmail'

7/17 https://t.co/bOsM0LgU1U

3Ô∏è‚É£ Handling the submit

Inside the 'useEmail' file we do a series of things:

üëâüèª Reset all submit state to default values
üëâüèª Check there was an email entered
üëâüèª Post the form to the serverless function
üëâüèª Await & handle the response

See attached for a breakdown üñºÔ∏è 6/17 https://t.co/3CTISc2Ewf

2Ô∏è‚É£ Submitting a form

So, what happens when we submit a form?

When we fill in the form, the useForm hook allows for the values to be set to state. Then once the form is submitted, it passes the values into the 'submitEmail' function within the 'useEmail' file. 5/17 https://t.co/cc2UwOV3qT

1Ô∏è‚É£  part 3

The main section we will focus on is the EmailSignup components, let's break it down in more detail:

üëâüèª 1: Gathering values from util functions.
üëâüèª 2: Form Components
üëâüèª 3: Displaying feedback to the user

4/17 https://t.co/iqKsEPajzo

1Ô∏è‚É£  part 2

The code in the previous tweet can be broken down into three individual components:

üëâüèª Outcome Message Container: Displays feedback after submitting
üëâüèª Email Signup: Actual form elements
üëâüèª Email Signup Form: Adds some extra elements like text and styling

3/17

1Ô∏è‚É£ Designing the email signup form component

Before we can build the functionality to facilitate the email signup we need to build the form people are going to use to sign up. Here's the code for mine and an example of what it looks like. 2/17 https://t.co/o7rCPaqGbK

üü£ #GatsbyJS: Email signup form for ConverKit üü£ 

Newsletters are a great way to market your content & build a following but to build your email list you need a way for people to sign up. Here's how to create an email signup form on GatsbyJS. 1/17
--
#100DaysOfCode #developers https://t.co/Ogv7n3zC9x
@djangmahprince Glad it helped üòÉ

@lincolnmorais @code I agree, I use ESLint & prettier as well but it's interesting to see that VSCode has this shortcut built in. 

I imagine ESLint uses this under the hood somewhere to allow for the correction on save. ü§î

üë§ .forEach()

I use a lot of the higher-order functions regularly in my code as I'm sure most people do. So I would approach this question from the perspective of what can I easily recreate with minimal code.

‚ùì What would you rather lose? ‚ùì

üåê JavaScript
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Higher-Order Functions

‚ùìIf you had to lose one of these from the language which would it be and why?
--
#100DaysOfCode #developers https://t.co/z4e8aJeumL

This is thread 27/28 in my February Twitter Thread Challenge. üìÜ

If you're interested in following along in my challenge or like this thread's content and want to see more please consider retweeting it for others to see and following me for future threads. üòÄ 9/9

‚ùì Got any questions ‚ùì 

If you have any questions or want more info on any of these methods let me know ‚è¨  8/9

5Ô∏è‚É£ .sort()

.sort() allows us to sort an array based on a compare function we pass in. 

Sort works by taking 2 values (a,b) and checking if one is larger than the other to ascertain the correct order. This is then returned as a new array. 7/9 https://t.co/H8uIJsz9xN

4Ô∏è‚É£ .filter()

.filter() does what it says on the tin, it filters the array down to a smaller size based on if each value passes/fails the filter condition.

In this example, I check if the value is an even number by checking if the remainder of dividing by 2 is 0. 6/9 https://t.co/fYzlQXpk3c

3Ô∏è‚É£ .reduce()

.reduce() is a special method that is often one of the hardest to learn due to how versatile it is.

With a .map() you operate on the values & return. But, with .reduce(), you can do pretty much anything.

In this example, I sum the values in the array. 5/9 https://t.co/OWQrnSMU3D

2Ô∏è‚É£ .map()

As mentioned for .forEach(), if you want to iterate over an array, manipulate the value(s) in some way & return the final results, you need to use a .map()

.map() and .forEach() are very similar, to tell which to use think if you need to return a new array. 4/9 https://t.co/FsRFSRGOnr

1Ô∏è‚É£ .forEach()

.forEach() allows us to loop over an array and access each item individually, similar to how a for loop would do it but in a nicer syntax. 

‚ùó You can't return values from a .forEach() if you want to return values you need to use .map(). 3/9 https://t.co/vWugcKEeGF

Before diving into the list, I wanted to cover what allows all of these functions to exist. They are all examples of 'Higher-Order Functions'. 

This is when a function operates on another. I covered it further in the thread linked. 2/9

üîó https://t.co/xkP46449fx

üü° JS: forEach, map, reduce, filter & sort overview üü° 

These 5 functions have become a staple of working with arrays in JS since they were introduced. Here's a quick overview of what each one does and how we can use them. üßµ 1/9
--

This is thread 26/28 in my February Twitter Thread Challenge. üìÜ

If you're interested in following along in my challenge or like this thread's content and want to see more please consider retweeting it for others to see and following me for future threads. üòÄ 7/7

üë§ My Favourite

Personally, I always go for the .map() or .forEach() method depending on the situation, in general, I've moved away from traditional loops when it comes to looping through an array.

How about you? üí¨ 6/7

4Ô∏è‚É£ .map()

.map() is actually very similar to .forEach() with one key difference. 

When using .forEach() we can only iterate through the array and not return anything. But, when we use .map() we can return values from the callback function as shown in the üñºÔ∏è. 5/7 https://t.co/0V5e8W3jLO

3Ô∏è‚É£ .forEach()

More recently introduced to the language, the .forEach() method is built into the Array.prototype and allows for us to directly loop over an array without calling a loop explicitly.

In fact, it actually uses loops underneath but just makes the syntax simpler. 4/7 https://t.co/TiycGxG7SF

2Ô∏è‚É£ While Loop

A slightly more unusual way of looping through arrays is the while loop. 

Similar to the for loop, the while loop will loop while a condition is true but unlike a for loop, it doesn't have a pre-determined end and instead will go forever while true. 3/7 https://t.co/Whb70O362u

1Ô∏è‚É£ For Loop

The for loop is one of the fundamentals of the language due to its versatility. It's no different when it comes to looping over an array.

The for loop works by creating a variable and incrementing it while a condition is true, we then access the index. 2/7 https://t.co/4cDExWkany

üü° JS: Looping over Arrays üü° 

Looping over arrays is such a massive part of handling data in JavaScript that I wanted to cover some of the most common methods of doing so in this thread. 

Let me know your favourite üí¨ 1/7
--

When studying it's good to have a central location to store your notes for future reference.

A good place to put these is on your website this allows you to help others as well & even get feedback to help you learn more. üí™ 1/2

urls.title: This is an obsolete API and is no longer guaranteed to work.
urls.description: The __proto__ property of Object.prototype is an accessor property (a getter function and a setter function) that exposes the internal [[Prototype]] (either an object or null) of the object through which it is accessed.

data.text:
‚ùó The use of __proto__ ‚ùó

I have used __proto__ a few times throughout this thread but this shouldn't be done unless for demonstration as this syntax is now deprecated.

Instead use, Object.getPrototypeOf & Object.setPrototypeOf

üîó https://t.co/92hXo0Q5mQ

15/16

6Ô∏è‚É£ Looping - Checking Object.prototype

You may notice that when we loop through the inherited properties, methods like '.keys()' are not shown, why?

Because the Object.prototype has the 'enumerable:false' flag & a for..in loop skips anything with this flag. 14/16

6Ô∏è‚É£ Looping - Checking if a property exists on the object

If you want to see if a property exists within the object or has been inherited you can by using: 

'Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty()'

This will return a boolean value for every property, see the üñºÔ∏è for more... 13/16 https://t.co/wIZnwS2I3I

6Ô∏è‚É£ Looping

If we want to see the properties on an object we can use 'Object.keys()' but this excludes inherited properties so we can't see the properties from the prototype.

If we want to do this, we can use a 'for..in' loop like shown in the image. 12/16 https://t.co/SYZnuGZxDz

5Ô∏è‚É£ ".this" example

In our getters/setters from earlier, we used 'foodShop.age = 10', this called the setter which used ".this". 

The " this" referred to 'foodShop' and not 'shop' even though the setter was stored within 'shop'.

Another example in the üñºÔ∏è  11/16 https://t.co/Bh3UyDc841

5Ô∏è‚É£ ".this"

The simple rule when it comes to using the "this" keyword with the prototype is:

**No matter where the method is found whether the object itself or the prototype chain. When calling a method the "this" keyword always refers to the object before the dot.** 

10/16

4Ô∏è‚É£ Accessor Properties Exceptions

The only exception to the read-only rule is getters and setters.

When using getters and setters we use the methods defined in the chain but the individual values are stored within the objects themselves. (More on this in a bit) 9/16 https://t.co/OvMO9Au7wD

4Ô∏è‚É£ Read Only

The prototype is only used for reading properties, when it comes to writing/deleting properties they are added or removed to the object it was called on regardless if it's in the prototype or not. 8/16 https://t.co/YbIjf8UD06

üîó Chain Examples

In the image, there are 3 examples showing the different situations of our example above.

1 - No Prototype
2 - One Custom Prototype 
3 - Two Custom Prototype

By default, all objects will finish with the last prototype being Object.prototype. 7/16 https://t.co/P9AJnRfsq2

3Ô∏è‚É£ The Chain

Prototypal Inheritance is actually quite logical, it looks within itself and then works up the chain every time it can't find the requested property.

This process continues until it finds the property or it reaches the end of the chain which is null. 6/16

...it looks within itself first, if it can find the property there it executes it. 

However, if the property isn't found within itself it then looks up the chain to the next link which we had set to the 'shop object.

As the property existed there it logged it out. 5/16

The reason we can log out the property from the first object by accessing it on the second object after setting the prototype is because of prototypal inheritance.

Once the prototype is set, the chain is formed. When we try to access a property on an object... ‚è¨ 4/16

2Ô∏è‚É£ Example

In the image, we have 2 objects with different properties in them. 

We try to log out the property from the first object by accessing it on the second object and unsurprisingly it doesn't work. ‚ùå 

But, once we set the prototype it works. ‚úÖ

Why is this? 3/16 https://t.co/KY3f0D3YbZ

1Ô∏è‚É£ What is it?

"Prototypal inheritance is the process an object uses in JavaScript to lookup properties and methods from its prototype should it not be found in the current object. "

Essentially, it allows us to use the methods and properties from another object. 2/16

üü° JS: Prototypal Inheritence Explained üü°

Prototypal Inheritance is one of those terms that sounds intimidating and complicated but it's not! In this thread, I'm going to cover what it is and how we use it. üßµ 1/16
--

This is thread 24/28 in my February Twitter Thread Challenge. üìÜ

If you're interested in following along in my challenge or like this thread's content and want to see more please consider retweeting it for others to see and following me for future threads. üòÄ 15/15

I've tried to condense down many moving parts into one tweet thread which I hope has made sense. However, I do plan on making a longer blog post in the future to cover the techniques used here in more detail.

If you have any feedback, I'd love to hear it. üòÄ  14/15

‚úèÔ∏è Example

If you want to see the cookie banner in action you can see it on my website at the link below:

üîó https://t.co/hVtzhYQeHP

If you want to see the code in more detail you can see it on my Github Repo:

üîó https://t.co/DYpz3Sl38m

13/15

‚ùóThe Law ‚ùó

Being GDPR compliant on a website has many moving parts and as it's the law, I would recommend seeking legal advice to ensure you're 100% compliant. 

This guide was an overview of how I added a cookie banner to my website for Google Analytics. 12/15

...force the cookie that controls the banner on my site to change to 'promptUser' and refresh the page. Due to the page refreshing, we re-run the onClientEntry API and as the promptUser value is now there, the cookie banner now appears asking for their consent. 11/15 https://t.co/IPZi5hpI8U

6Ô∏è‚É£ Being able to opt-out

Another key principle of GDPR is being able to remove your consent for data tracking at any point, I wanted to make this easy for users.

So in my custom hook from earlier, I built a function that can be run at any point which will... ‚è¨ 10/15

5Ô∏è‚É£ Cookie Banner Logic

Inside the Cookie Banner Component, there are a couple of functions handling the onAccept and onDecline. 

These 2 functions change the 'promptUser' value to either be true or false. 

Then if accept, remove the opt-out cookie set by default. 9/15

4Ô∏è‚É£ Prompting the user

If the user enters my site with either no cookie or it set to 'promptUser' then I display the cookie banner from earlier to prompt them. 

This is done via the Layout and Cookie Banner Component. 8/15 https://t.co/4HDCWUlSt4

‚ùóDefault Opt-Out

As mentioned earlier one of the big points for GDPR is by default the user should be opted out. This means by default we need to set the ga-disable cookie to tell GA to not track the user.

This is done in gatsby-browser.js with the gaOptout function. 7/15 https://t.co/g7iVwyhoFM

3Ô∏è‚É£ Gatsby Browser

A lot of the 'magic' happens in the gatsby-browser.js file, using the API onClientEntry, I check if a user has a cookie saving their preference for analytics. From this, I can take the appropriate action. 6/15

1Ô∏è‚É£ Start tracking
2Ô∏è‚É£ Prompt
3Ô∏è‚É£ No tracking https://t.co/FiU0sPys0e

2Ô∏è‚É£ Cookie Hook

I made a custom hook to handle the logic of checking if a cookie is present or not and to handle re-prompting the user.

The important part of this file is the 'checkForAnalyticsCookie' function it allows us to check if a function is present or not. 5/15 https://t.co/NyPMSQRqgG

‚ÑπÔ∏è Info

‚ñ∂Ô∏è For Google Analytics I'm using the plugin: gatsby-plugin-google-gtag
‚ñ∂Ô∏è I've set this plugin up to prefix all the cookies with 'https://t.co/7OMpjkd4Uk' <- This allows me to easily identify which cookies are Google Analytics so I can manipulate them later. 4/15 https://t.co/yJPb87Ops5

1Ô∏è‚É£ Cookie Banner Design

Before getting to the logic, we need to come up with a cookie banner design. (see mine in the üñºÔ∏è)

Most importantly to be compliant with GDPR, the cookie banner can't impede the user's experience. You must not lock functionality behind acceptance. 3/15 https://t.co/o4DhBGAplL

‚ùóImportant Points ‚ùó

To be GDPR compliant there are a few things we need to cover.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Analytics must be opt-in only. By default, the analytics must not collect data.
‚ñ∂Ô∏è A user must be able to revoke permission at any point.
‚ñ∂Ô∏è The user must know what data is used. 

2/15

üü£ GDPR Compliant Cookie Banner on @GatsbyJS üü£

GDPR compliance is a large topic & it covers many aspects of websites, most importantly the use of cookies. 

In this thread, I wanted to cover making a cookie banner for Google Analytics. üßµ 1/15
--
